attachments.title: NASA Explains Why June 30 Will Get Extra Second
attachments.text: The day will officially be a bit longer than usual on Tuesday, June 30, 2015, because an extra second, or “leap” second, will be added.
attachments.fallback: NASA: NASA Explains Why June 30 Will Get Extra Second

attachments.title: Othermill — Other Machine Co.
attachments.text: The Othermill is a portable, computer controlled (CNC), 3-axis mill specifically designed for small workspaces. Our mill is compact, clean, and quiet enough for use at home, yet produces professional-quality work in metals, woods, waxes, and plastics. The Othermill will be at home on your desk, in your workshop, or on your kitchen table.   The Othermill is available exclusively in the USA. We will be expanding into international sales as soon as we can. To be notified when international shipping begins, please sign up below.     What are the system requirements for the Othermill? Otherplan , our “what you see is what you make” milling software that guides you through the milling process, runs on Mac OS X 10.8 or higher.   What file formats does Otherplan support? Eagle: .brd Gerber: .gtl and .grb G-Code: .nc and .tap   What other file formats will Otherplan support in the future? We plan to support other types of .svg files, as well as .dxf, .stl, and .obj. As we integrate these new filetypes, we’ll automatically share these free updates with all Otherplan users.   How fast can the Othermill go? The maximum traverse speed (rapid) is 1,000 mm/min and the maximum spindle speed is 12,000 rpm. Otherplan will help you set the optimal cutting speed based on the materials and tools you use.   The Othermill includes a 90-day warranty . For more information on the Othermill, please see the Othermill Overview page .
Open source kits to build a machine for milling plastics, woods, and metals
attachments.fallback: Open source kits to build a machine for milling plastics, woods, and metals

text: I think shapeoko and inventables used to be working on the same product, then they diverged recently
I might want a laser cutter before a CNC router or mill though
could we design and build a low-cost 3d scanner?
is that something we could do as a product?

It’s possible. I know the research team at UW was building a room scanner using a Kinect and the Rome In a Day project’s algos (<http://grail.cs.washington.edu/rome/>). If we started with the Dell Venue 10 tablet, it has the RealSense cam onboard, and it’s Android. And I know the guy who ported the toolkit. :simple_smile:
Idea being, we could scan by hand, then use the RIAD algos to stitch the model together
Nice! That would be super cool
